overview: The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [8] It also establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [8] Additionally, the Act requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [8]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [8] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services, and the establishment of two temporary positions. [8] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [8]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided documents do not specify the assumptions or methodology used to determine the appropriation amounts. [8] However, the Committee on Judiciary finds that closing the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area of the Third District is imperative, based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure. [9] The committee also notes the Third Circuit is at a disadvantage to address crime motivators due to limited community resources, funding, and geographic restrictions. [9]
agency_impact: The Judiciary will be responsible for making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [8] The Judiciary will also establish the women's court pilot program within the third circuit Kona division, which will be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [8] The Judiciary is also required to submit multiple reports to the legislature regarding the new pilot program and the need for programs in other circuits. [8] [8]
economic_impact: This measure aims to support women dealing with trauma, abuse, and unhealthy relationships by providing substance abuse treatment and mental health support. [9] [9] The pilot program's goal is to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism. [8] This addresses issues in Hawaii County, which has the highest poverty rate in the State, high rates of domestic violence, and limited opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women. [9]
policy_impact: This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove its repeal date. [8] It establishes a new temporary three-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [8] The measure also shifts the focus from a previously proposed interim study for the Third Circuit to requiring a report on the need for pilot programs in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [9] [9]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [8] The sums appropriated are $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [8] No other revenue sources are identified in the provided documents. [8]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the Kona pilot program. [8] The Kona pilot program is established as a three-year program, suggesting a third year of funding will be required for fiscal year 2027-2028, though no amount is specified. [8] The Kona pilot program is repealed on June 30, 2028. [8] The bill also makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent, implying ongoing fiscal obligations that are not funded by this measure. [8] The judiciary is required to submit a report to the legislature prior to the 2026 regular session regarding the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in other circuits. [8] Additionally, the judiciary must submit reports in 2026, 2027, and 2028 on the status of the Kona pilot program, including recommendations on whether it should continue or be expanded. [8] [8] These reports will inform future fiscal implications. [8]

fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Kona pilot program established in Part III of the act is repealed on June 30, 2028, ending its fiscal obligations. [8] However, the bill makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will result in ongoing fiscal implications beyond the six-year period. [8] The costs associated with the permanent program are not specified in this measure. [8]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The current version of the bill significantly changes the scope and funding from the previous version. [9] The pilot program is now established in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits as previously proposed. [9] Unlike the previous version which had unspecified appropriations, this measure inserts specific amounts of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [9] This version also adds two temporary FTE positions for the Judiciary, whereas the previous version had no FTEs and considered unspecified positions for the Department of Health. [8] [9] The requirement for an interim study to establish a blueprint for a program in the Third Circuit was deleted, and a new reporting requirement was added for a needs assessment for other circuits. [9] [9]
fte_positions: This measure includes funding for the establishment of two temporary positions. [8] The positions are one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist position. [8] This is a change from a previous version, which deleted language that would have appropriated funds for an unspecified number of temporary positions for the Department of Health. [9]
appropriations_changes: Appropriations were previously unspecified. [9] These funds are specified for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [9]
funding_sources_changes: The funding source for the appropriation is the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. department_impact: This version of the bill specifies that the sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary. [8] This is a change from a previous version, which included language that would have appropriated an unspecified amount of funds to the Department of Health. [9] The language appropriating funds to the Department of Health has been deleted. [9]
reports_required: The bill requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026 regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [8] Additionally, the judiciary must submit annual reports to the governor and legislature prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028 on the status of the Kona pilot program. [8] The previous requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint was deleted. [9]
pilot_program: This measure establishes a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits as previously proposed. [9] This pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [8] The bill also makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [9]
sunset_date: Part III of this Act, which establishes the Kona pilot program, shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [8] The bill also removes the June 30, 2025 repeal date for the First Circuit's pilot program, making it permanent. [8]
effective_date: This Act shall take effect on April 23, 2057. [8] This effective date was inserted to encourage further discussion. [9]
